MurmurHash.cc

00001 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00002 // MurmurHash2, by Austin Appleby
00003 // (public domain, cf. http://murmurhash.googlepages.com/)
00004 
00005 // Note - This code makes a few assumptions about how your machine behaves -
00006 
00007 // 1. We can read a 4-byte value from any address without crashing
00008 // 2. sizeof(int) == 4
00009 
00010 // And it has a few limitations -
00011 
00012 // 1. It will not work incrementally.
00013 // 2. It will not produce the same results on little-endian and big-endian
00014 //    machines.
00015 
00016 #include "Common/Compat.h"
00017 
00018 namespace Hypertable {
00019 
00020 uint32_t murmurhash2(const void *key, size_t len, uint32_t seed) {
00021   // 'm' and 'r' are mixing constants generated offline.
00022   // They're not really 'magic', they just happen to work well.
00023   const uint32_t m = 0x5bd1e995;
00024   const int r = 24;
00025 
00026   // Initialize the hash to a 'random' value
00027   uint32_t h = seed ^ len;
00028 
00029   // Mix 4 bytes at a time into the hash
00030   const unsigned char * data = (const unsigned char *)key;
00031 
00032   while (len >= 4) {
00033     uint32_t k = *(uint32_t *)data;
00034 
00035     k *= m;
00036     k ^= k >> r;
00037     k *= m;
00038 
00039     h *= m;
00040     h ^= k;
00041 
00042     data += 4;
00043     len -= 4;
00044   }
00045 
00046   // Handle the last few bytes of the input array
00047   switch (len) {
00048     case 3: h ^= data[2] << 16;
00049     case 2: h ^= data[1] << 8;
00050     case 1: h ^= data[0];
00051             h *= m;
00052   };
00053 
00054   // Do a few final mixes of the hash to ensure the last few
00055   // bytes are well-incorporated.
00056   h ^= h >> 13;
00057   h *= m;
00058   h ^= h >> 15;
00059 
00060   return h;
00061 }
00062 
00063 } // namespace Hypertable
